(Redacting things out of a concern of her privacy; the location pin is the default location for the city in CL)

Had a nice deep talk with some friends an hour ago (Sat, 5/26 at 12 midnight) about not having a set criteria about picking someone to date based on their pedigree - that one would judge others as "not worthy" before even getting to really know them, and how bad of a place that would lead :(

Tired, and out of a concern for safety, I decided to take an Lyft Line back to my place. I saw the car was picking up someone from the Exchange Place PATH station, so I figured I had a few minutes to hop on. I had greeted you and the driver a gentle "Good evening", and you both returned pleasantries. By the time we reached my place, pleasantly surprised, you had told me we were neighbors, and what street you lived on - the street opposite mine (i.e. that you were going to be dropped off a short distance after my place). With a smile, you reached out to shake my hand and introduced yourself as K.

I was too shy and stunned to reply with more than my first name (S) and wish you and the driver Marin a safe evening. Why would a stunning lady risk introducing herself after midnight to a guy she had just met?

Even if we don't cross paths again, I'd love to know that you got home safe, and get another chance to properly introduce myself face to face. thank you for surprising me :)
title: Neighbors crossing paths after midnight

...huh?

Radio silence. 

Irish exits. 

That seems to be your thing.

A Scooby-Doo mystery is unfolding.

The truth is, Joe Fox, that I really want to text you... to see how you are. The truth is, my honey bunches of oats, that I want you to text me... to see how it's hangin' up here.  

The truth is, I really just want to understand where you're at and how you feel and how you actually feel about me. I just want to solve this case once and for all.

The truth is, I care quite a bit about you.  

But, I won't text you... because it takes two to volley and you're up next to serve some quips and phrases. 

(And, because I already feel like a twerp.)

The truth is, I think it's kinda silly that you'd rather push me away than have a wonderfully awkward moment face to face... and enjoy the experience whether we hit it off or not. 

IRL could surely never feel as cold as this. You must know this.  

Winter is over and there ain't no time for sharp little icicles...

...only flowers and sunshine and that frolicin' we talked about.

I'm here for you. I've never not been. 

Yours remotely, 
Kathleen Kelly (or something like that)

ARTIST IN SEARCH OF LOVE STORIES!

Have you carved your name or initials as a declaration of love in the cement sidewalks of New York City?

Please come forward to contribute your love story (whether romantic, friendship, of familial) to an art project about the hidden love stories on the sidewalks of Manhattan.

Be part of a unique portrait of love in NYC!

If you submit your love story:
- you will receive a signed and small edition photograph of your heart/declaration of love.
- your love story will be included in the project, Concrete Hearts of Manhattan.
- you will be credited for your contribution. (Stories may also be submitted with first names only or anonymously.)

Details to include:
Where is your heart/declaration of love located?
When did you make it?
Who is it for?
What made you decide to carve a heart/declaration of love?
Tell us your love story.

(Please only submit if you actually carved a heart or other declaration of love or had one carved for you - real love stories only please!)

Of particular interest are hearts in:
Greenwich Village, the East Village, the West Village, and NoHo,
but ANY HEART in ANY SECTION of the city will be included in the project as long as it can be photographically documented.

This is a unique opportunity for you to share your love story with the world!

Further opportunities for your participation and recognition are possible.

If you have questions before you're ready to share your story - please contact me!

Share the love,
Meg

Meg is an artist in NYC who undertook a two-year artistic journey walking every sidewalk between 14th St. and Houston St. to photograph the declarations of love discovered in concrete. These streets comprise the neighborhoods of Greenwich Village, the East Village, the West Village, and the small neighborhood of NoHo. Approximately 102 miles were walked with a total of 1182 hearts found.

VISIT TO VIEW THE PROJECT: meglyding(dot)com/concrete-hearts
title: Have you carved a heart in the cement of a NYC sidewalk?

Hi,

We sat across from each other. On flight 103 from Abu Dhabi to NY. I wanted so badly to exchange numbers, and to see if you wanted to spend some time with me. I could not get the courage to talk to you. I cant stop thinking about you, and feeling like I missed an opporunity to start an amazing friendship. You are a extremely good looking Asian man. I love to travel, and I am open minded, but sonewhat conservative at the sametime. I am not sure how long you will be in NY. I think I heard you tell a flight attendant you are from Thailand. You were wearing Kaki pants and white sneakers, you were extremely good looking, and seemed to be very reserved. I like you alot.  And my eyes are longjng to see your face. I am here, hoping you see this, and that we could be friends.  We walked side by side for a little while in the airport. I was just not sure how you would respond.  I want to ask you out for movie, diner, and a walk along the promenade.  I would like to get to know you.

body:
QR Code Link to This Post
            
        
Hi Patricia,

A long time ago, when I was just getting separated, we had a fantastic phone conversation, and you told me that you didn't want to date someone so newly single. Well you were right of course, that journey was difficult and I wasn't ready.

But I've been ready for a long time now, and I remember you as the sweetest kindest person. At the time I didn't know how rare that was.

Now I wonder about us sometimes. I remember your amazingly goofy pictures and I think we might have really been a match.

If you read this, write to me.

Kyle
